body: Film producers like nothing more than a chest-burstingly uplifting, against-the-odds, underdog-come-good, overcoming-adversity story, and Leicester City’s tilt at the Premier League title is about as chestburstingly uplifting as they come. So just as football journalists have been sharpening their pens and documentary-makers loading up their editing suites over the past few weeks as the Foxes have been closing in on the championship, film production executives will have begun the unseemly jostle to get Leicester City: The Movie in the works.  But how to go about it? The first issue is where to pitch it. Notoriously, most films about football – about British football, at least – have been pretty bad: hamstrung between the need to appeal to the widest possible only-vaguely-interested audience (ie, the US) while not alienating the rabid, intensely knowledgeable home support. The poorly received Goal! trilogy fell between every stool possible. (One of its writers, Adrian Butchart, is the man talking up a potential Jamie Vardy movie – but this, like much else in the film world, is a case of attempting to hype a film into existence.) The Damned United did a good job in dramatising Brian Clough’s relationship with Peter Taylor, but the actual football left a bit to be desired. Mike Bassett: England Manager mined Graham Taylor’s discomfiture for laughs, but Leicester City: The Movie won’t be a vehicle for satire.           ‘Walt Disney wouldn’t script this’ – Leicester City champions    Acquiring sources is an important part of the development process – especially in Hollywood, where producers are often hit with nuisance lawsuits claiming plagiarism. The Leicester Mercury’s Rob Tanner looks to be ahead of the pack with 5000-1: The Leicester City Story – according to the publishers, no one has come in yet to pick up the rights, but that’s surely a matter of time. This leads to the next question: are we looking at a cheeky, chirpy, cheapo British film; or a heartwarming all-guns-blazing Hollywood epic? Eddie the Eagle or Jerry Maguire? The Match or Rush? We could very well have duelling Leicester City movies on our hands, if the recent manoeuvres over another great news story, the Hatton Garden Job, are anything to go by. The outfit that brought us The Guvnors put a cheeky-chirpy British version swiftly into production, while a big-shot Hollywood producer announced a heist film with the possible involvement of Michael Caine. So who would play whom? Here’s our stab at a cinematic teamsheet. The man at the helm     Who’d bet against it? … Claudio Ranieri, AKA the Tinkerman, Leicester City managerl; and actor Tom Hanks. Photograph: Getty Images/WireImage    Claudio Ranieri, manager – played by Tom Hanks By any rights, the role ought to go to The Great Beauty star Toni Servillo, an authentically great Italian actor with the right blend of soul-searching whimsy. But after that crack about putting a bet on Leicester, Hanks has put himself firmly in the frame. If he’s up for it, no contest. Best defence Kasper Schmeichel, goalkeeper – Tom Felton Felton – Draco Malfoy to you and me – is already a master of the bottle-blond look that Schmeichel has inherited from his dad. Christian Fuchs, full back – Christoph Waltz He might be a bit old to play a professional footballer, but Christoph “Blofeld” Waltz is probably the only German-speaking actor Anglo-American audiences will have heard of.  Danny Simpson, full back – Craig David A dodgy-musician cameo is a fine addition to any Hollywood film, and Simpson would appear to provide the best opportunity.      The big man … Leicester’s victorious captain Wes Morgan; and Idris Elba. Photograph: PA/Getty Images    Wes Morgan, centre back – Idris Elba Imagine Luther in shorts. The Leicester captain, with his on-pitch gravitas and commanding physical presence, would be a decent cameo for a heavyweight British actor. Worth putting in a call to Elba.  Robert Huth, centre back – Matthias Schoenaerts Even though he’s Belgian, Schoenaerts would be a good bet for the hulking German centre back, notorious for getting stuck in where it hurts. Might have to lose a little muscle bulk though, to approximate Huth’s beanpole physique. Marking in the middle Danny Drinkwater, midfield – Jack O’Connell There’s got to be a place in the line-up for British cinema’s current golden boy, star of ’71 and Unbroken. Leicester’s midfield engine room could be the pick. N’Golo Kanté, midfield – Omar Sy Sy, star of the massive French hit Intouchables, could make the role of the tough-tackling midfielder his own – plus help hoover up some of that chunky French box office, the biggest in Europe.     Mercurial … footballer of the year Riyad Mahrez; and actor Tahar Rahim. Photograph: Getty Images    Riyad Mahrez, midfield – Tahar Rahim The Algerian PFA player of the year has – spookily – his almost direct screen counterpart: French Algerian actor Rahim, star of epic gangster film A Prophet. If anyone can get inside the mercurial Mahrez’s skin, it’s him. Marc Albrighton, midfield – Matt Smith A boyish 26, Leicester’s eager-beaver wide man isn’t especially high in recognition terms, but floppy-haired former Doctor Who Smith has got a definite lookalike thing going on. Up front and personal     Well, he’s got the hair … Jamie Vardy, record-breaking striker; and Tom Hiddleston Photograph: Getty Images    Jamie Vardy, forward – Tom Hiddleston The Foxes’ goal-getter is their own breakout star, probably their only player recognisable to those not really interested in football. Unfortunately Wilfrid Brambell is no longer with us, so we’ll probably just have to make do with Hiddleston: if he can play Hank Williams, he can play anyone. Shinji Okazaki, forward – Jackie Chan Japan isn’t short of actors, but hardly any of the younger generation have got international recognition. Hollywood has never been shy of messing around with ethnic identities (see Memoirs of a Geisha), so let’s throw Chan into the mix. Leonardo Ulloa, forward – Oscar Isaac A bit-part player in this season’s events, but Ulloa has come good in the final reel to help see Leicester over the line. Since everyone loves Isaac after Inside Llewyn Davis, here’s a good opportunity for a dramatic walk-on. Show me the money     Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, chairman; and the ever-versatile Tilda Swinton Composite: Rex/Getty Images    Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, chairman – Tilda Swinton Since no one outside the Leicester boardroom knows what the club’s Thai chairman and CEO of King Power Duty Free, Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, looks like, you wouldn’t be surprised if they went for some serious stunt casting. After Swinton has finished playing the Ancient One in Doctor Strange, she might be fancied to take this on.
webTitle: Foxes at the box office – who would star in Leicester City: the Movie?
